content: Linux. When XEDIT is started, it looks for the configuration file XEDIT PROFILE. Not all CMS virtual machines always have a copy of this file; therefore, XEDIT sessions can look and behave differently, which can be a problem. The steps in this section help resolve this issue for you. If you are unfamiliar with XEDIT, a cheat sheet is available in Appendix B, “Reference, cheat sheets, blank worksheets, and education” on page 475. This appendix also includes the URL to the z/VM Library where you can obtain more information. This section guides you in the configuration of the XEDIT profile for system-wide usage. More importantly, these steps also provide the understanding to use XEDIT functions to add, move, and change text. You use XEDIT substantially through the rest of this book and in the administration of your z/VM environment.
